title: Pitching a Risky Idea to Senior Leadership
description: You need approval for a bold idea that challenges the status quo. Leadership is generally risk-averse.

options.label: Lead with emotion to inspire them (Pathos)
options.explanation: Emotion alone won’t reduce perceived risk. You may inspire curiosity, but this audience needs certainty.

options.label: Assert authority and push the idea hard (Might)
options.explanation: Pushing creates resistance, especially with senior stakeholders. They don’t like being pressured.

options.label: Lead with evidence and risk-reduction data (Logos)
options.explanation: This is the strongest approach. Risk-averse audiences respond best to data, precedents, and predictable outcomes.

teaching_points: Match tactic to the audience's risk perception.
Use Logos + Ethos when challenging the status quo.

title: A Teammate Isn’t Supporting Your Project
description: You need a teammate’s support, but they seem disengaged and unmotivated to help.

options.label: Offer something valuable that helps them first (Exchange)
options.explanation: This is ideal when motivation is low. A costly, unselfish offer changes the relational dynamic.

options.label: Escalate to your manager to force cooperation (Might)
options.explanation: This may get compliance but damages the relationship long-term.

options.label: Appeal to logic explaining why the project matters (Logos)
options.explanation: If they're disengaged, logic won’t shift their motivation.

teaching_points: Use Exchange to shift low-motivation situations.
Leading with generosity creates influence over time.

title: Navigating a Conflict Between Two Team Members
description: Two colleagues on your team are in conflict, disrupting progress. You're not their manager but need the team to function.

options.label: Take sides with the person you agree with more (Pathos)
options.explanation: This escalates the conflict and destroys neutrality.

options.label: Facilitate a structured conversation where both share perspectives (Procedural Fairness)
options.explanation: This creates fairness, voice, and mutual understanding — often reducing conflict.

options.label: Avoid the situation entirely and hope it resolves
options.explanation: Avoidance rarely resolves interpersonal conflict and may worsen team performance.

teaching_points: Procedural fairness can defuse strained relationships.
Your role isn’t to solve the conflict — but to create the container for resolution.
